Florida Prepaid became a hassle for me since I have a scholarship that requires survey taking in order to disburse its aid to you as well as contacting the university to make sure it is accepted.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Honestly the school does not offer enough help for student financially. Besides financial aid students have to pay for everything on their own.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Scholarships are limited as it is such a large school. Talking to people about financial aid is not a hassle, and they can be helpful. However it is up to you to force the issue of finding aid. I would suggest talking to them in person, not email as they probably receive nuerous emails a day.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The financial aid UF provided was exactly what I needed and I had no problems.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Unfortunately I am in the awkward financial situation of not having a low enough income for financial aid and not having enough money to pay for school so I have to take out loans. I am also a white, American female with a little above average grades which doesn't help.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Did not receive financial aid
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Wish they gave me more, still applying for scholarships
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: My #1 tip for anyone trying to get financial aid at UF is: fill out your FASFA on time! You will not receive any aid if you do not do this and the faster you get it done, the faster they can come up with a package for you. Most of my aid came from loans from the school, as well as Bright Futures. I did receive a merit based grant at one point, but it was soon lost when my brother stopped attending college elsewhere. Unfortunately, there do not seem to be many scholarships available through the university. However, other options exist. One option that I swear by is Federal Work Study. You can request this on your FASFA, and then if you get it you will be allotted a certain amount of money that you can earn through a work study job. UF has many such jobs open to students, both on and off campus. Most are minimum wage jobs, but if you search around enough you can find higher paying jobs. I, myself, ended up with a cushy job tutoring children for above minimum wage and I loved every second of it! I think the best part about these jobs is that they are close by and are willing to work with students with a busy curriculum.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: little aid for middle class
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Just fill out the FAFSA as soon as possible. I submitted it the day before it was due and because they received it three days later they did not give me financial aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They assume that since your parents make money that they will pay for your entire college experience. I don't thinks its fair that my parents income effects the amount of aid I could receive.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The school gave me more loans than scholarships...
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It was a hassle because you had to get everything done in a timely manner.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I got some aid, but not as much as I truly needed.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I am paying for school my self although I am dependent of my parents and their income is too high to qualify me for aid, which I am not happy about because I am paying for it my self . Not with my parents income.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Getting the government financial aid is very hard.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I am not very familiar with the process.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I just applied for my Bright Futures and I had no trouble receiving it every semester.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: My first year I had no trouble, but my second year, half of my aid was taken away from me without any sort of explanation.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They really do not care about trying to give me aid
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Salem State University is unorganized
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid office should offer more scholarships to students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Getting grants and scholarships is like winning the lottery, there is almost no way to guarantee help even if you are very intelligent, active, and in need. There is no compassion from the aid office.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Getting any financial aid is so hard, they give out nothing and I'm just waiting until they finally give me something other than loans
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The school itself doesn't give any scholarships to me.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I ended up receiving the financial aid I needed but my dad had to first appeal what we were originally given becuase it was insufficient.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There were a few mistakes made, but I got the aid I needed in the end.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: UF does not give out many scholarships.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: UF doesn't offer many scholarships or grants
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Getting financial aid was very difficult because of all the documents needed and the lack of feedback from the financial aid office until the last minute.  Also, they won't send any emails or notifications or update the status of your financial aid on their website unless you call or visit the office to remind them to do so.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: It's difficult, but everyone is very helpful. Scholarships are tedious and a hassle as well but worth it very much.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It could always be better - for example, I'm graduating in the fall, but I can't use my after-fall aid (spring 2016) for the summer 2015 when I really need it, in order to graduate. Kind of stupid there.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The process is generally a hassle for me simply because of financial strains. I've also lost scholarships as a result of my estimated parental contribution going up. I temporarily lost a scholarship as a result of some extenuating circumstances, but was refunded the scholarship on the condition that I receive therapy. When I was undergoing the process of appealing that scholarship, my financial aid adviser gave horrible customer service, and at one point had given me false information on due dates adding more stress to myself and the adults involved in my case. It seemed like a miracle that I was able to get all the paperwork on time, because I was heavily dependent on that adviser. Once we managed to get all the paperwork in, a different adviser helped me easily and quickly. I relied on her instead for all my needs. Her kindness and depth of knowledge lifted a lot of weight off our shoulders and I'm happy to say that I can continue to afford attending this university with her help.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Was never sure I would get financial aid until the day it came in.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I have Florida Prepaid and Bright Futures, but nothing specifically from Florida. So far they have, together, covered my tuition and housing.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Applying for financial aid was easy, I did not have any problems. I wish there were more scholarships available to students.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Applying from out of state, I was already put into consideration for a variety of scholarships without needing to fill out any extra applications. I received a scholarship that covered a good portion of my tuition which is good. Definitely make sure you apply to the university early because obviously the earlier you apply, the earlier they can consider you for financial aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Bright Futures just gets deposited in your bank account - couldn't be any easier.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Do all your research on your own and only go to them if you have any specific questions.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: My financial aid process went pretty smoothly and I had no hassles. The school I attended before UF was always giving me headaches with my financial aid. UF made it clear which documents I needed in order to get my financial aid in line before the deadline.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: My financial aid process has been relatively smooth as I apply for FAFSA months ahead of time.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: While the financial aid process went smoothly for me, I will say this: you must actively check up on your account to make sure the amount is accurate. Any mistakes are fixed quickfast.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: It's great to be a Florida Gator
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: A degree from the University of Florida will open many doors and provide many opportunities to students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Very hard to receive financial aid or scholarships
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Usually pretty good about aid distribution but it is a hassle to accept it and keep track of it
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: While UF is a very STEM and engineering-bases school, I feel like it's reputation would make any kind of degree comparatively valuable.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Scholarships and dealing with the financial aid office is pretty tedious, but manageable.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I ended up getting enough scholarship funding to cover literally EVERYTHING. The state of Florida gives out very generous scholarships to its top students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: UF offers you loans and you can accept of deny them online, very easy
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Didnt get anything but bright futures
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Didn't qualify for any financial aid and also didn't get any scholarships but that's probably expected because there's like 50k students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Not too many people get school grants.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There are so many opportunities to get great jobs and internships. Career Showcase is held every fall and spring semester and a lot of great companies go to recruit UF students.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Going through the process of knowing the benefits, the backfires, and the usage of financial aid is very confusing. Where do I go? What do I do? The emails provide some unexplained information.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Only on a little bit of financial aid but everything helps and it went smoothly.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I have received my financial aid promptly each semester and the office staff is pleasant and informative.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: This school is prestigious, offers many AP classes, and has graduates attending ivy leagues universities.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There's simply not that much money to give out to students. I personally have Florida Pre-paid, so that takes care of a lot of my worries, but you have to look for extra money on your own if you're not really in "need".
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It is extremely tough to receive grants or aid from the school itself. Your only option is FAFSA and outside scholarships.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I'm still dealing with financial aid, the people working are not helpful at all and it seems like they just don't care sometimes.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid to me was a hard task to get my hands on. The financial aid i was given was enough to cover room and tuition, but that left my books and other needs in the air for me to take care of myself.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Great place to earn a degree from
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Academic grants should be readily available
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I have a lot of need based assistance, which has been very helpful. The financial aid department and bursar offices are helpful in case of trouble.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: To get credit for the aid you receive is not difficult, but a very smooth process.  The problem is with getting scholarships, especially those not associated with the school.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I have attempted to receive financial aid in the past, but was turned down, even though my Dad had just become disabled and could not work, due to a spinal condition.  My Mom works and they stated that she makes too much money as a teacher.  I haven't attempted since then, and that was two years ago.  I need it desperately, due to being in grad school now, for accounting, so Bright Futures and Florida Prepaid are getting ready to run out.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The financial aid disbursement went smoothly, but the process to get it was frustrating. To get in contact with people in the SFA office, you have to send multiple emails and voicemails.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: APPLY EARLY!!!!! I was undergoing family issues dealing with the death of my father and his estate and debt at the time of applying for colleges and when I went to apply for scholarships I was told that it was first come first serve and there were no more left even though I met more requirement that some of the students I met that had received the full ride scholarships. I am now drowning in student loans and doing everything I can to try to scrape together the money for school, housing, and food.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: School hooks you up with a grant for your first year then takes it away your second year. Even with a high gpa. Totally sucks,
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There are many services for post grad career search
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Getting scholarships at UF is very difficult, it is costly to go here and there aren't many scholarships offered to incoming freshmen. Outside scholarships are the way to go, and if you have Bright Futures and Florida Prepaid, you get a refund that depends on how many credit hours you take, which is pretty awesome but I had to find that out on my own.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It is not extremely easy, but it is possible to get financial assistance and receive a good amount of aid from the school.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid process at UF can be long and drawn out at times
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It is very difficult to receive any financial aid other than the Bright Futures Scholarship. The FAFSA does not always represent the core financial situation of the students, which causes some students to be declined needed financial aid
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: A degree from the University of Florida is a great achievement and will help tremendously when applying for a career.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: There is a huge Alumni base in Florida and it really helps students build connections when applying for jobs.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Since my pharmacy program is among the most competitive to get accepted I believe that  the value  of the degree is higher compared to other schools. Students are provided with many oppouritnites for jobs and intern projects. There are research opportunities and guest speakers from all over the state we can network with to get jobs and internships from. Our program also hosts a career day every year where most of the potential employers come and do job interviews with students.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: UF has a huge alumni network that's great for after graduation.  In addition, the career fair always has a ton of great companies hiring, and the Career Resource Center is very helpful.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: As such a prestigious school in this state, there is hardly any merit-aid like other schools. Applying for University scholarships is not discussed with students (found the directory on my own and have never heard anyone mention it) and a complicated process. I have received a need-based grant from the school for each semester I have attended so far though.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: sometimes the process is easy but if you want summer aid, it is way to hard to even get that
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The benefit of attending college instate is Florida Prepaid and Bright Futures which helps with financing the price of college. The lines waiting for the Bursar and Financial Aid office become packed, so get there early if you need to clarify with anything!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: UF only gives 55 scholarships to 6000+ incoming freshman. It is very competitive but I received sufficient government aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid is rarely given, unless the student has an extremely low family income or is a minority. If you have neither of those aspects, the best you will get is loans.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Financial aid came in right away. I took out another student loan and went in my account on time.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Financial aid is fairly easy to attain, and the aid office is very helpful, but as soon as aid is lost due to academic probation it seems nearly impossibe to get it back. My tip: dont make stupid mistakes.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I received a bright futures scholarship from the state of Florida for my undergraduate experience. I had no problems receiving it, and was not qualified to receive any other aid.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Financial aid is great but unfortunately there arn't many scholarships for fine arts major( almost non), I finally applied to a Hispanic scholarship but still waiting to here from them. Money is tuff when there is no one to help. Most scholarships are for math,science, and engineering majors; not art majors.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Haven't been able to get one yet for grad school.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: The process can be kind of long, but every semester I receive the aid I need.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The financial aid process is somewhat difficult to go through. The website they have to show what you have recieved is not very clear.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Just complete FASFA as quickly as possible to get the aid you need as soon as you need it. Then apply for the loans you want and it should be straightforward from there.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Do not really on your ISIS financial aid award disbursement information. Be persistent and proactive with the Financial Aid office and eventually you will get the information you need.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: We have an exceptional scholarship search engine
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The only "financial aid" i got were loans. I graduated high school with excellent grades and my SAT was above average, however I got no reward for it. My dad is the only person in the household who works and even though he makes very decent money, it is still hard to get by with just loans that I will eventually have to pay back.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Getting loans is easy, getting scholarships is difficult. Apply for scholarships through the individual colleges, the university itself won't give you anything. It is also very aggravating that they don't take into consideration that the student is not supported by their parents, even if they are still "dependent" because they are under the age of 24.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Process has gone well for me every year
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I feel like it is no different than the process my brother and sister went through at their public universities, but financial aid processes in general are worrisome.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Stay on top of it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid is something that needs to be done with time. Rushing it or doing it last minute could make it a hassle for yourself.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I had no problems getting aid, but some students had to wait weeks until aid arrived. I would say to be a little patient, because they do have a lot of students to go through.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: About average, but I recommend getting to know your representatives and being nice to them. They are more than willing to help.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Some financial aid officers doesn't care, and gave a horrible advice. Some do go beyond
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The financial aid process is tough sometimes. To receive aid you can apply through your college since they have a lot of scholarships to offer. The bigger the college, however, the tougher it may seem to be awarded a scholarship. Most scholarships have very specific requirements, but it seem there is a scholarship for every major and interest.

Value.Review: I got all the finical aid I needed and expected PLUS the university even gave me extra scholarships I didn't even expect that helped pay for lots of extra cost I originally planned to pay out of pocket. It is like the school is paying me to go there!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: While I was not offered any scholarships as a transfer by previous financial aid went through after communication between the financial aid offices and the scholarship provider
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I never had a problem.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: My experiences are better than most, but I also worked hard to get my gpa and activity list. I earn a lot of scholarships for that
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It's really hard to get a concrete answer because different staff will tell you different things about your aid.
Value.Author: College Junior

I've never had a meal plan personally but I worked at Pollo Tropical (one of 2 healthy options) and I can tell you that business was always backed up because those who look out for their health don't want to eat processed foods like Panda Express and Wendy's every day.

Food.Review: There are so many places to choose from that are delicious in any variety. UF has one of the best vegetarian and organic selection of on and off campus dining. The cost is average and student discounts and specials are everywhere in abundance so searching for the right affordable place should be really easy.

Food.Review: The food is good on some days, but otherwise it can be sickening to eat the same thing over and over again. Sometimes it makes you miss a good home cooked meal time and time again.

Food.Review: I love the options that we have off campus.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: I had a meal plan for my athletic scholarship and I rarely used it due to the bad quality of food that they serve in the dinning halls. I even had training table, which was in the back end of the dinning hall for athletes and I still feel like the food quality could be better.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: It's okay for first year students in order tot ease themselves getting adjusted on campus otherwise I would not recommend it.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You have a lot of choices to pick from without having to pay ridiculous amounts.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The dining hall gets really old towards the end of the year. I would suggest not getting the unlimited plan, after a month or so you don't use it as much. Otherwise, you do have a decent amount of options that are included in you rmeal plan if you plan the use of your flex bucks right.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are many great restaurants in Gainesville. University drive has Kebab house, karma cream and many other great quick eats.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are numerous restaurants on campus such as Chick Fil A, Papa John's, Subway, as well as many others. Many of them are inexpensive and quick in theory but when lines are long the on campus places take a long time in order to get food. There is a good variety but it would be better if the variety included more healthy options because much of the on campus food is pizza, Mexican food, and other unhealthy options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Most dining options are right between the highway and campus, so they're typical highway-strip kind of places. There is fast food, restaurant dining, sandwich shops... a really good variety. Cost is average and student discounts are nonexistent outside of some clothing places.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food and dining on campus is pretty typical for a large university. A lot of fast-food and convenience. Dining halls are decent but loaded with sodium, so if you like that then you're good. Meal plans are a waste of money - it's a lot easier and less expensive to go without one.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a ton of restaurants on Archer to choose from!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Luckily everything on UF is relatively close so even if you aren't a huge fan of chick-fil-a, subway or the Pod, Midtown is not far from the Hub and has a good variety of food choices but they are not affiliated with UF so you cannot use the meal plan to pay for it!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: cafeteria was dirty and had bugs
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Some diversity but be careful
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Pricey but a good treat
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Gainesville has so many good places to eat. There are several restaurants in Gainesville that I don't have at home and will really miss when I move away from Gainesville. One such place is called Relish. It's a burger joint with the quality and price of a Five Guys, but with so many more options! The best part about them is that they are open really late, til about 2am most nights! Another great restaurant Gainesville has is called Peach Valley cafe. It's a breakfast and lunch restaurant, but my favorite part about it is the breakfast! The food is great, the service is better, and the cost is reasonable! It's a very popular restaurant; I don't think I've ever gone there without having to wait at least 5 minutes for a table, but it is so worth it! Overall, I'd say Gainesville has a huge selection of dining options, and everyone eventually finds a place that they swear by, and that they can't find anywhere else!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: University of Florida has such a wide variety of food to eat on campus. There are so many restaurants, and they are all ones we know and love. I think the best part about the campus food is how accessible it is. There are restaurants and convenience stores everywhere so you never have to go too far away from classes for a meal or a snack. I would definitely not recommend eating on campus everyday just because it can get a little pricey, but if you forgot your lunch and can spare the cash the University of Florida has some awesome options for food.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: good local mom and pop selection
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: nasty and poor selection but take care to eat healthy
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Theres a huge variety of healthy options especially.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There could be healthier food but as far as taste, there's many places to eat that are great!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Much better variety than on campus but it's all pretty unhealthy.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Not enough variety, Why do we have four subways with three being within a two minute walk of each other?! Panda express is gross and unhealthy, you got rid of home zone which was the only reasonably priced place with real food. The dining halls are gross and have awful food. Do you even take students into consideration when you decide on restaurants?!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Like any good city it has tons of awesome restaurants with varying prices.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's definitely not the worst food around, but it's also not the best. It's pretty good for the price though.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: most don't offer student discounts
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I'd say it ultimately is worth getting the meal plan for at least one's first semester, just to see how it plays out with the student. Some will find it very convenient (which it is; it's generally just a walk away from your dorm), while others will find it to be paying for poor quality food. The dining hall food isn't always the best, but it is pretty consistent with its breakfast options (eggs, potatoes, sausage), and there's always a salad bar and a sandwich station that you can't go wrong with. The vegan and grill stations usually have pretty good food. I don't eat much around campus, like at the Reitz Union food court, though the Croutons place can make you a great salad. If you don't get the meal plan, flex bucks are certainly worth it, as they can pay for certain items at the food court not necessarily on the meal plan, as well as other amenities, like any item at the P.O.D. markets. Gainesville does has some good, legitimate restaurants off campus (The Top, Burrito Brothers) that are definitely worth checking out.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The off-campus dining is as good as any dining. There are many options
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: All of the food you can think of is on campus, but dining halls are a little expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It is very convenient, especially on those late night runs for good food in midtown.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: If you're willing to travel a bit of a distance their is a lot of options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's pretty average. None of it is tii bad, but it gets old pretty quick.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I don't usually eat off campus but when I do it's reasonably priced.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The dining hall is extremely convenient but on certain days the food options aren't too great, especially on weekends. The flex bucks option is a life saver and let's us enjoy delicious places such as Chick-Fil-A.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Not very many healthy options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love going to Mothers with my friends every week, and there is a great variety of places.

Food.Review: There is a Chick-Fil-A at the heart of campus, so it's good.

Food.Review: As far as off-campus dining, Gainesville pretty much has it all. From big-name chain restaurants to local places, you'll never run out of a new place to try while living here.

Food.Review: I'd say pretty average as far as campus food goes. The dining hall food is decent as well as convenient. However, I do think that there should be more healthy options and less fast food.

Food.Review: It is better than on campus.

Food.Review: It's ok, I just wish it was healthier!

Food.Review: There's a lot of off campus dining

Food.Review: The campus food is okay, not the healthiest but it's got a decent variety.

Food.Review: Off campus dining is great.  Though there are almost always waits at the very popular restaurants, they are popular for a reason and are great places to eat at!

Food.Review: Campus food is very fair.  The food in the dining halls is only good during the "Preview" sessions.  The options for restaurants on campus is good, but it would be much better if they were open on the weekends at least for a few hours.  I had a meal plan during the summer and rarely went to the dining hall.  I would have gone more often had the meals been more appealing.

Food.Review: So many more options than on campus

Food.Review: There are a lot of off-campus dining options, but I don't have a car so it is often difficult to go out to eat.

Food.Review: There is a lot of fast food on campus. I would like for there to be more health food options. We also have P.O.D. markets, but they are very expensive.

Food.Review: It's great, only bad thing is a lot of places are in Butler, which is hard to get to without a car.

Food.Review: Chic-fil-A is my go to place, but I'm definitely in love with panda express (though I never go to the reitz, so its inconvenient for me)

Food.Review: I don't think I've ever received a student discount for off-campus dining options, but the University offers plenty of coupon books. I don't eat out too much but we do have a lot of Hispanic, Asian, and Middle Eastern cuisine here. I definitely have favorite restaurants (Mi Appa, 4 Rivers Smokehouse, Southern Charm Kitchen, Bagels and Noodles), but I try not to spend too much money on going out because university is so costly. I don't think the price of food here in Gainesville is anymore expensive than my hometown as long as the establishment isn't located on campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I don't really rely on on-campus dining options so I don't frequent many of the places UF has to offer. Every now and then I will buy chick-fil-a, go to subway, or get a sub from Little Hall Express. I try to avoid buying food from campus because I find that the better value is easily any place else. The options are slightly more expensive than usual and refills aren't free. As ridiculous as the latter sounds it is a complaint I never cease to think, or hear from other students. I believe that a lot of universities are driven by monetary gain now more than ever, and the dining options are easily an example of that. If I purchased something on campus it would be something that was already pretty cheap, or I'd have to be desperately hungry (to the point of being physically unable to perform) and unable to walk to an off-campus location. As dramatic as that also sounds, as a college student every little purchase adds up, and I just don't have the money to afford to go out to eat. So not eating for the duration that I am on campus is something I find myself doing often. This is not unique to me, plenty of my working class- lower class peers practice similar habits. Spending more than 30 dollars a month on food is just not an option for us, if we want to be able to keep up with the other major expenses that going to university has (outside of the tuition) such as paying for books, for access to do homework, access to supplemental mandatory class materials, for tutors to teach the materials in certain classes that students generally struggle to learn from the professors themselves (studyedge, tutoring zone), parking decals etc.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You can eat at once place every week and not go to all the locally owned restaurants in town. These local places are often very high quality, great cost and provide large portions.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Campus has tried to get better about providing variety and healthy food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: This campus has a lot of fast food readily available. If you like Panda Express and Chick fil-A, then it's all good. Fortunately, there are Krishna meals (delicious) available as well as actual food in the hospitals (which is not cheap).
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: There's a lot of variety off campus, on 34th and University.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a lot of great restaurants with many diverse options.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: I would prefer a greater variety. There is a lack of healthy options on campus, and too much fast food options.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Midtown and downtown have a good number of diverse restaurants super close to campus that range from affordable to a nice spot for a nice date/ask your parents to take you when they visit. Butler plaza and Archer are a bit further but are also good options to grab food that is highly diverse.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: For college food I don't think it is that bad but it is nothing like what your parents are going to cook for you at home. The dining halls are actually really good somedays and there are others where nothing looks or sounds good, at least for me. We have five Starbucks on campus now which is awesome, but always expect a line at them. You can use your meal plan at places like Subways and Moes after 4 and you can use your flex dollars at the Pod markets or at any restaurant on campus not on the meal plan.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lot of places to eat, and always new places opening
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Lots of different restaurants close to campus.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The off-campus dining is superb; there's a lot of great options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I don't live off campus currently, but the few times that I have been off campus, there are a good variety of restaurants to eat at.  I can't complain.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: One of the things I love about Gainesville, is the off campus dining. They have a variety of restaurants and they are so delicious! Food is top of the line and there is always variety.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Lots of variety and quality for the price.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Many different restaurants or fast food chains are around the school
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There aren't a lot of organic/ vegetarian spots except for the farmers' markets.

Food.Review: So many options for anyone and everyone, especially in areas right off campus

Food.Review: The off campus dining is varied, convenient, and cost efficient.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I live off campus so its my only option
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Because it is Gainesville, the food is costly.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Comes in handy, especially late at night
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: TONS of places to eat. Lots of variety and cool hangout spots with great food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are several local establishments as well as chain restaurants in Gainesville. There are a lot of off-campus dining options on the outskirts of campus too that are walking distance from classes. Archer has a huge variety of food options from fast food to nice restaurants.

Food.Review: there are a variety of restaurants. Some places keep their cost low for students
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: we have a pretty decent off campus dining scene. There are a bunch of local small, mom-and-pop places to eat as well as a bunch of chains.

Food.Review: There are plenty of options both right off of campus and around the Gainesville area. Go explore! There is a great mix of chain restaurants and local places. All of them delicious.

Food.Review: It's pretty good for how small this town is.

Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Everything is very convenient and I often receive student discounts

Food.Review: I normally buy my own food to cook because I live off campus in an apartment. I rarely go out because of the cost, but the places I have been to are great.

There is a range of restaurants, ranging from Latin Bars to Indian Cuisines and Middle eastern Dining Specials. The diversified class of restaurants is extremely well rounded and very convenient for students living on and off campus.

Food.Review: I live in an apartment style dorm, so its pretty rare that I go out to eat.  However, there are several places that deliver to campus that are pretty cheap, fast and tasty,  There are also restaurants, like Peach Valley, which is a popular breakfast place, that is about average cost, but really good quality.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Gainesville has a great variety of cuisines.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The off-campus dining is what you would expect, complete with fast food restaurants and the like.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Many option, and good prices for sure
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are so many restaurants in Gainesville to fit every price point
Food.Author: College Senior

Having a car opens up even more options, Archer Road being an entire road filled with places to eat.

Food.Review: It's great but I prefer to eat at home
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I rarely eat on campus
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The dinning halls are expensive for a meal plan and the food is alright. The meat is not cooked very well
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Unbelievable specials on food every night of the week. Very affordable
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There are many places to eat all over Jacksonville since it is a very large city paticurlaly in the riverside area
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There's some really great local places to try, especially in the downtown area.  Favorites include Leonardo's Pizza and the Top.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The dining halls aren't too bad, and there's usually a lot of decent options.  The Reitz and the Hub have several choices for when you get tired of Broward or Gator Dining.

Food.Review: Plenty of chain restaurants and fast food stops, but definitely some cool local shops as well.

Food.Review: As someone who doesn't like to cook, I enjoy the food scene on campus. Definitely a lot of fast food (Chick-fil-a, Burger King, Papa John's, etc.) but there are a couple healthier options, and the dining halls always seem to be the healthiest place to go on campus.

Food.Review: It's not a metropolis but for a country college town it's very impressive. Lots of hipsters contributed great stuff, and weirdly the best place is Reggae Shack? Idk get the ox tail. Homemade vegan ice cream at Karma Cream, fancy study time lattes at CMY (owned by part of the band sister hazel???) hungover brunch at Flying Biscuit, pizza in a van at Satchel's, anything from the top, barbecue from Pearl's... Y'all are welcome.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: So many places to eat down on Archer: chains, fast foods, and some quality places. Eating out is a bit pricey once you add up all the times you go out to eat.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Not a great amount variety although there is variety nonetheless. It is rather convenient although I believe the hours of operation should be extended.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Lots of dining halls and options on campus.  I like to use my flex bucks so that I don't always have to eat in the dining hall.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I had a meal plan my first two years, but now am living in an apartment.  I love the convenience of the on campus restaurants.

Food.Review: Lots of variety. Gainesville caters to the University crowd.

Food.Review: Located close to archer road which has everything you could ever need or what on it.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Always have nice variety but the quality isn't so great and the servers give you very small portions.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Its convenient and I get fed. At the beginning of the year the food is great, but as the year goes it gets more bleh. For me its mostly just convenience.

Food.Review: There are a lot of places to eat for a reasonable price, I like it.

Food.Review: Easy to eat healthy if you want to.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Off campus is prime, Jimmy John's is the hero of them all.

Food.Review: I haven't eaten at many (maybe once or twice total) to form an educated opinion

Food.Review: You can always find what you are looking for to eat in Gainesville! Especially if it is fried :P

Food.Review: Lots of options to choose from for whatever you crave.

Food.Review: So many places to try, most if not all are great and have there personal ups and downs.

Food.Review: Average. It's mostly the same around most campuses

Food.Review: Plenty of variety, and I am discovering more unheard of places the longer I live in the city.

Food.Review: Lots of options both healthy and not. always something I'm in the mood for
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a ton of chains, but also some very cool eclectic, mom and pop type places if your willing to ask around and venture a bit further off campus.

Food.Review: You won't go hungry here!

Food.Review: I'll be sad when I graduate because I can no longer have any food delivered to my door.

Food.Review: There are enough options to have a different meal from a different place every night for well over a month!

Food.Review: I always find myself eating from somewhere new in Gainesville.

Food.Review: I wish they were closer.

Food.Review: You need a car to do anything within a reasonable amount of time.

Food.Review: Plenty of off campus dinning options exist

Food.Review: Tons of food options catered to anything and everything that students will spend their money on.

Food.Review: As a student who lived in off-campus her first semester, I was truly excited by the number and variety of restaurants located right down the street from my apartment. In the mood for Mexican? Tijuana Flats, Moe's, Willy's Mexicana Grill, and La Nopalera are all located within a mile of each other. Fast food craving? Chick-fil-A, Taco Bell, Wendy's Burger King, Panda Express, McDonald's, and Steak n' Shake can all be found just down the street. Maybe you want something fancier? Downtown is a great location for date night with restaurants like Vello's, Dragonfly, Harry's Seafood, and so much more. While the food may not be good for a college student's wallet or waistline, it sure will satisfy your taste buds.

Food.Review: There is a great variety of choices and not everything is so expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a lot of great restaurants and new places open all the time
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Never really went out to eat somewhere.

Food.Review: Drive down Archer Road and you'll have every chain and fast food restaurant at your ready.

Food.Review: Again, I am not on the meal plan so I really can't provide much insight. The few times I have eaten the dining hall food though, I enjoyed it.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The nightlife is wonderful and the people are amicable. Food is also top quality and plenty of variety.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a lot of flavorful options and the quality is fantastic. I eat there whenever I can.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There is something for everyone.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: They have a wide variety of food for all dietary needs.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: So many great restaurants here!!!  There aren't a ton of big chains, though I wish we had a Cheesecake Factory.  The local restaurants are great and food is tasty for a good price.

Food.Review: I had a meal plan during the first semester of my freshman year and that was IT. It was overpriced and not very good.  Near the end, I was just eating pizza and pasta and sandwiches.  Gator Corner is better than Broward.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The vegan scene in Gainesville is awesome, the TOP is great and most places are relatively inexpensive.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The food options are pretty limited, and there are no sit down restaurants on campus. UF mostly has fast food places like Chivk-fil-A, Subway, Panda Express, Burger King, and Papa John's.

Food.Review: They are not open late at all. They all close early.

Food.Review: Off campus dining is second to none everything is always perfect

Food.Review: Lots of variety and big name fast food and even the dining halls are very good

Food.Review:
Though I consider the meal plan somewhat pricey, I'm pretty satisfied. The dining halls have stands just devoted to vegan/vegetarians, so it's not hard to be healthy at UF. I've actually yet to meet someone who gained the "freshman 15", most people actually lost weight. 

The best part about UF's meal plan is the IMMENSE variety of options. I can use my meal plan at the two dining halls on campus, Subway, Crouton's, Home Zone, Camellia Court Cafe, Moe's Southwest Grille, Chomp It, Pollo Tropical, Papa John's and Burger King. As for flex bucks, those can be used at eateries like Starbucks, Chik-Fil-A, Einstein Bros Bagel, Panda Express, KFC, Boar's Head and more.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Eateries are right across the street from campus. They're super tasty and cheap, and give out discounts (like coupon books worth) every semester.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There's a lot of variety, and are some places that are hard to find but are completely worth finding. There are also a lot of start-up restaurants that are delicious and fairly priced. Prices all around can vary from cheap to expensive depending on what is being ordered.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Has a good variety of food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Plenty of chain fast food places on campus. Those are cool because you can use your meal plan at a lot of them. Dining halls are okay.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I eat off-campus way more than on. I think there's plenty.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It's good for several weeks and then you get tired of it quickly because of the repetition. Often times I would find myself going in and spending $10 on just a salad because nothing else was healthy or appetizing enough. I feel if they included more vegetables and cranked down the amount of carby foods, it would be better.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is a meal plan for most students (that I don't use), but from what I know, it does allow students to use many of the restaurant options in the area by using their student IDs.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: On campus dining is good. If only the reitz food was open later
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I really like how late most of the dining options are open for and that they deliver.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: My friends and I usually hit up the same places every weekend, but there are a mountain of other places to go eat/hangout.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There's so much good food restaurants here - and they're open late some nights!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love the off-campus restaurants. There are a lot of fun, local places with really good food. Most of them are within walking distance too. I wish that they did offer more student discounts, however, as I prefer not to spend a lot of money on food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I really do not like the campus dining, but some people do. It's not the best quality food and does not offer much variety, so you get sick of it pretty quickly. There are healthy options, however so once again, the dining hall experience is mainly up to the student. I choose not to go there very often. I prefer to eat at on-campus locations that I can pay for with my student ID because I have declining balance.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I had a meal plan during my whole first year as a freshman. Convenient when you're living on campus so you don't have to have cooking supplies. Open late and usually pretty yummy. OMG COOKIES. After several months, the food got a little repetitive. Luckily, there's several restaurants on campus where you can use flex bucks throughout the semester
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I currently live in Infinity Hall and its been absolutely amazing! I love that its a brand new building and how convenient it is to all my classes.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Rawlings Hall was a very good location with quick access to most of the classes within a 7 minute walk. Also very close to Broward dining which was good for quick snacks. The building was a bit older but I still enjoyed Rawlings very much. Community bathrooms and kitchen aren't a problem although having to walk all the way down the hall can get annoying at times. The rooms were big enough but it's a dorm so don't expect too much space.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Lived in springs. It was a good community, but at certain times of the day, by the time bus got to our stop, they were full and I'd have to wait for 2-3 buses to go by before i was able to get on one.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It really depends on where you are. Some locations are great, others are lacking.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's noisy and smelly but fun for Freshmen.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Most dorms are old and expensive for what the students get out of living there. They are a great place to meet like-minded people.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are quite small and it seems they're not taken care of much
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It is nice being close to classes and everything on campus, but housing is a little bit of a pain.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms are run down and most don't have private bathrooms
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Unless you are getting off campus, extremely new, expensive and hard to get housing, the general housing options are fairly poor. The buildings are old and not renovated. The cleanliness is low and the buildings are dirty both on the outside and the inside. Where most colleges offer bathrooms inside the dorms, most of the dorms here have community style bathrooms. There are very few apartment-style or even split dorms available.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Never used housing at UF.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The campus dorms are relatively clean and the bathrooms are cleaned once a day.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I lived in Beaty towers and to start off, the view was just phenomenal. I was on the 12th floor overlooking the Gator Nation. The cleaning staff came once a week, and they were very sweet and often asked us how our transition from home to school is going. The cost was about average. I loved having a kitchen and bathroom in my room.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I did campus housing for my first semester and it was alright. I had an apartment-style dorm with a full kitchen but the only downside was that it was very far from the center of campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Although my dorm gave great memories, it was barely renovated and very old. I wish the bathrooms had been nicer, as well as the mold infested rooms.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Personally I feel like the dorms are good for the most part, but can be slightly on the crowded side.  However, I stayed in the Infinity dorm, which was too expensive and far from campus for me to like it very much.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on campus has its ups and downs. I would say the perks of living on campus would be being extremely close to classes and dining halls. On the other hand, parking on campus is a headache and dorms are pretty small.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I will forever hold the fond memories I had in the dorm called Yulee during my freshman year in college. It was a great way to meet new people.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I never lived on campus but everyone I know does not say terrible things about it.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing was as expected for freshman, but still enjoyed it
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Lakeside is far and spacious but private
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Overall, campus housing is very convenient to class, clean, spacious, and easy to obtain preferential housing. Of course, every person varies on their opinions of living on campus, but I have lived on campus going on three academic years now and have no complaints. However, I would strongly recommend either not doing random roommate request unless you are not very particular or have a roommate in mind already for the year.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The dorms were a great experience for freshman in terms of meeting new peers and being immersed in campus life.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I had some issues, but overall enjoyed living on campus. I made a lot of friends and it made the transition to college much easier.

Housing.Author: College Junior
