Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Very convenient in terms of access to classes and on campus activities. However, my dorm was rather old (lived on 4th floor and no elevator), and there were only 3 washers/3 dryers for a building of about 200 students. Dorm mates are friendly, though hygiene for some is questionable.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are nice, its hard to get good roommates though. Nice and clean, also great spaces to meet friends
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I live off campus and truly enjoy the scenery of Gainesville!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Dorms on campus are fairly nice. They are somewhat overpriced, but there is a certain level of convenience when it comes to living on campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Some dorms are better than others. Most of them are fairly similar. The rooms are fairly small especially if you get stuck in a triple.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus housing is too limiting, the rooms are small and greatly overpriced for the amenities offered.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: For the price I paid to live in my dorm last year, I was disappointed in what it had to offer.  The elevators were almost always broken, the building had mildew and inefficient appliances.  Although close to classes, there were really not many other perks to making this dorm my home for 9 months.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I only lived in a dorm for the first summer I was at University of Florida. I can say it was a great experience, I did have to share a room and bathroom. The only thing I did not like it the cleaning staff had to enter our rooms to clean the bathroom and sometimes came way earlier then my classes started.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: My experience was good. Great for 1st and 2nd year
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I loved getting the freshman experience and highly recommend living in a dorm for your first year. But after that get out! it definitely makes you appreciate personal space
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most people room in Broward their first couple of years because it has the best location on campus but the older students get the apartment style dorms like Key's complex which is farther from central campus. There is no dorm that has excellent location and excellent interior.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I personally thing that housing at UF is alright. It's not amazing but it is also not horrible. I think I feel this way just because I am definitely not a fan of public bathrooms. That's the biggest thing about the dorms that I do not feel to fondly of. Other than that, sharing a room and being close to people is super cool. It kind of forces you to make friends unless you really really don't want to. The next biggest thing that I don't like about dorms are the prices. Off campus housing is definitely what I am doing from now on. The housing costs more than the tuition!!!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus is pretty awesome. It's convenient and comfortable, but without a car, one may feel trapped on campus as there is not much to do in a college town off campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: My dorm like was really great this year. I stayed in Buckman, which was recently renovated and so was very nice and the halls only had 8 girls on a floor. Everyone was super nice and respectful.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I don't really know. I think there is a good variety of old and new, modern and traditional.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I've been living in Lakeside for about two years now, it's fine I guess. Rooms are small, but it is apartment style so there is a kitchen and private bathroom within your apartment. The prices are on the more expensive side but isn't all campus housing overpriced?
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I briefly lived in a dorm for my first summer semester then moved to an apartment. My decision didn't have anything to do with the quality of UF dorms but it was more cost effective. I recommend living in a dorm to meet people.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Every dorm has different perks and downfalls. Some are closer to the dining hall or classes than others, some have better utilities.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I enjoyed living on campus my freshman year since I met many people and it was close to campus. However, the room was really small and the rules were a hassle.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The dorms are pretty well kept, and most are in convenient locations for classes. Not all dorms have a good social atmosphere though.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's convenient.  It's close to food and classes.  I've been spoiled.  I have lived in Hume and Infinity, two of the top dorms.  They're amazing.  Some of the older ones are not as nice, but the convenience of not having to clean your own bathroom outweigh a lot of cons.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Dorming was an experience I would only do one time. There is not much space or privacy, especially if your roommate generally ignores you and brings their friends over all the time to just hangout on a school night and you just want to go to sleep.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most dorms are old and dirty. The new dorms are over priced.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I had a fantastic experience in both Beaty Towers and Maguire Village, but it almost cost me everything I had. Expensive but enjoyable and quality.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are many different dorms sprawled out across the large campus-- They all are decently nice, but I would recommend trying to stay as close to the center of campus as possible.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The floors are clean daily, I commend the cleaning crew as they do a great job, but with upwards of 100 students to one bathroom, things get disgusting fast
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorm life is very enjoyable. The rooms were clean and organized coming in and therefore made it comfortable to live.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love living close to all of my classes, but there are truly cheaper housing options off-campus, and it really sucks to have to share amenities and bathrooms.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I mean it's not the greatest thing but it gives me a convenient place to live while I'm in school.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: While the dorm I lived in was nice, it made life very very difficult.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Great to meet other freshman
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Location is everything for me and Dorms are right on campus! I could do with a little more room, but let's be honest, who actually gets that in dorms?
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are a lot of rules and limits to living in a dorm. I say the only great perk is that its very close to your class location.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms aren't bad, they are okay. Definitely an experience for first years. The convenience of living on campus is great.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus you met some amazing people who become your friends. By living on campus you live in a whole different community. All of the dorm options are amazing and there are many options for what type of dorm you would like. The cost is not super great, it could be a tad lower but all of the amenities are great. And there is always something to do in the dorms, whether it is hanging out with friends, studying, or attending an event.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: My only complaint is that the people on my floor do not do a very good job at cleaning up after themselves; finding hair mats in the shower is the worst!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: This campus is the best.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The best part about living on campus is the proximity to classes and libraries. The dorms aren't very spacious though, which is a big drawback for me. I'm also weirded out by communal bathrooms.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: housing is good just too expensive
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Some of the dorms are nice and close to campus but there are plenty of dorms that require a bus ride to get to campus and all the apartment style dorms are small and out of date.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Great atmosphere to be in.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I do not live on campus but the campus has a good atmosphere.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I had a crowded housing situation and didn't really find a community outside of my roommates. Seemed hit or miss.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Somewhere to live. Don't get what you want most of the time
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The best option to choose for on campus housing would be apartment style since all the other options does not include a kitchen within the living area. The dorms are a little bit expensive for what the school charge. They are pretty convenient since they are so close to your classes. The application process is pretty easy.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I live in broward and love it. It was recently renovated, so the rooms and bathrooms are new, clean and updated. Each floor usually has occasional get-togethers in the lounge so everyone gets to know each other. The cost is not too bad and it's very convenient being next to classes and food.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: A lot of the buildings are old, but then again, the school has been around for over 100 years!  I lived in Jennings my freshman year so I made sure to upgrade to Springs for my sophomore year; after that, I moved off-campus, as most do.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: The dorms here are really expensive. The worst options on campus include Sledd Hall which has mold problems. The dorms though are really close to classes.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing experience on campus is overall average, nothing great but not bad at all. My dorm building last year was one of the oldest ones, and it showed. But, it was an experience and I would recommend incoming freshman to share this same experience. There are now new dorm building such as infinity hall, it looks beautiful and new on the outside. The froward area is probably the most popular, it is in the center of campus and close to everything. I would recommend living here if possible for a freshman.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I lived in a Broward Hall triple room my freshman year. I loved the social aspect of living at Broward and had great roommates. Aside from the social aspect, Broward wasn't the most comfortable place to live. I had to share a tiny room with two other girls and on top of that share a bathroom with several other girls at the end of the hall. I was constantly getting sick due to living in such close quarters with so many people. Looking back, I spent a lot of my time at Windsor Hall because one of my friends lived there. Windsor was in the perfect location for me because its right by sorority row which is where I eat all of my meals. If I could go back I would probably live in Windsor as opposed to Broward.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I live in Hume, which is one of the nicer dorms, so I think my dorms are pretty nice. However, I have also been in some dorms where the sanitary conditions of communal bathrooms is not that great, and the size of rooms aren't always great either.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: When I applied for housing, I logged on late and the only rooms still available were economic triples (doubles with three people). I was a little nervous at first, but it ended up working really well. My roommates and I are living together next year too!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I've really enjoyed living on campus, and am going to continue to do so next year.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are plenty of options. It is expensive, but definitely recommend for first year students.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I was happy to live on campus freshman year because I could easily be involved and my dorm would just be a short walk away. I overall felt safe because campus is always busy no matter what time it is. The dorms are old, but I think living on campus made it easier to make friends, get better sleep (since I could walk to class), and regularly attend events and meetings since I didn't have to take the bus there. My RA was also awesome with getting to know us, having free food and get togethers and talking to us one-on-one. I even went to her after a bad break-up. My RA was probably one of the few RAs that did this because most students just said that their RA didn't even talk to them.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The Murphree area is beautiful. I unfortunately got stuck in a triple, but honestly it's a pretty large room.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I was not a fan of living in a dorm, I am happy to be in an apartment now.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living in close quarters with one or two other people is certainly different from having your own space at home, and that can be difficult to deal with. However, the housing options to make students happy are extensive. There are single rooms, double rooms, triple rooms, apartment style, suite style, and luxury dorm options. The best dorms are Beaty Towers, Cypress Hall, and Jennings Hall. The worst dorms are some of the older buildings, but for the most part everything is pretty decent. Dorms are EXTREMELY well placed in terms of proximity to classes and to the more popular parts of town. The housing process is easy to understand and almost everyone gets their housing preferences.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: People lack respect in some areas, some places lack certain convinces but the benefits sometimes manage to make it slightly better and rules never seemed to be enforced or cared for. RA's do not really seem to care and only provide superficial guidance or help.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most residential buildings around campus will be near classes that students must take, but some end up being on the other side of the campus. Students have to plan classes around their residence locations at times.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I lived in Beaty as a freshman and it really wasn't bad. The location was pretty centralized, but I didn't like having 3 roommates and the room was SUPER SMALL. My little sister lived in Lakeside when she went to UF, and it had an attached bathroom which was nice, but it was SUPER FAR AWAY from where the classes were. I didn't even know that area of town was considered part of UF campus. It's crazy. I would definitely recommend students get a dorm close to classes, like Broward or Beaty or Windsor Hall.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Do not live on campus
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Communal bathrooms shouldn't be a thing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I've lived on campus for two years and I've loved it. It's super close to everything, making it super convenient, and the RAs are so nice. Not to mention, the dorms are beautiful! The only reason I didn't give the highest rating because it is a little more expensive than living off campus would be.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The buildings are always in great condition and are always clean
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I like the LLCs (Living Learning Communities).  I live in the Engineering LLC, primarily b/c it is located next to all of the Engineering classes and buildings.  Also, I like having fellow Engineering majors to live with.  The dorm is traditional: small, sometimes dirty, very basic.  Still, for the location, it's very convenient.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living on campus is great! Along with the adjustment to living on your own, the conveniency of living with a fifteen minute walk from all of your classes provides the comfort of running back to your dorm in between classes, and getting some fresh air walking to class. The dorms are, in my opinion, the best way to meet new people! Whether cooking together in the kitchen, catching up in the social room on your favorite TV shows, or participating in one of the fun dorm socials, fun new friends with cool interests are right around each corner.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love living on campus. I can sleep a little more before class.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms are great as a first year option, but not really beyond that.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on campus is the easiest way to meet other freshman your first year, but it doesn't offer much past the social atmosphere
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The buildings are outdated and I believe I am not getting my money's worth in my dorm. I live in a triple, which turned out to be really cramped. My roommates and I are currently looking for an apartment off campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: While it isn't luxury, its sufficient while living on college.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living in Cypress is the best
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love where I am located on campus and it's fairly clean for the most part. There are a lot of activities in my area.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Its pretty awesome, except everyone's roommate sucks..
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The only thing I have about dorms are the cost, other than that, I love living in campus. However, I live out of campus after my first semester at UF.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are many off-campus housing opportunities and many different ones to choose from. Most of the housing includes many amenities with pretty reasonable cost.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: i was in an older portion of broward dorm in a triple so it was tight living space.  met a lot of great people though and it was a great campus location
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: some rooms are very old and need to be fixed
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Via my personal experience, I lived in one of the oldest dorms on campus my freshman year and it was awful. The bathrooms were community bathrooms and disgusting, the air filters were nasty, and the closet space was almost non-existent.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The housing is plentiful and accommodating.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most dorms are fairly close to the bulk of buildings you will be attending as a freshman. The dining halls are close-by as well as many of the other buildings you might need access too like the libraries and Reitz Union.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I have loved living on campus. My roommate is great! I would advise people to look on the Facebook page to help find a roommate.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: My housing experience has actually been excellent. I have found so many great friends in my hall. I also live in a triple and I thought it would be so crowded but it has not been as bad as I thought.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
I lived in Hume Hall, which was a dorm with two beds, a sink and a closet to share, and a bathroom that is shared with the neighboring room (no communal bathrooms yesss). They have a crew that comes in and cleans once a week so the facilities are really clean. I really liked Hume. Some dorms to be noted:

Graham, Simpson, Trussler are all near tennis courts, a large field + concert area a mini grocery/convenience store, and a swimming pool. 

Lakeside is far from campus but it's a nice area. You get your own room in an apartment with three other roommates and two bathrooms. There is also a kitchen and a living room area. 

Beaty is a 14 foot tall apartment style building. Fire alarms = going down 11 flights of stairs. They're pretty cozy though and close to Chick-Fil-A. 

Keys and Springs are similar to Lakeside but a bit larger, except usually reserved for upper class men. 

Murphree area halls are older and closer to the nightlife but old and some without air conditioning. 

Cypress and Infinity are new dorms. I don't know much about them except they look really nice. 

The others are your run of the mill basic dorm + communal bathroom.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I lived on campus my first year. It is a great experience to have but I would not do it again. It was cramped, there is no space, and you can get really unlucky with a weird room mate. But it is convenient how close it is to classes.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Bad options, far from campus, not good amenities.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are okay, but they are old buildings and just refurbished a little bit. Some don't have air conditioning. It was nice to live on campus, close to class. There are not many single rooms, and the few single rooms are pretty gross.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I haven't done off campus housing, but I heard t's great
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: A variety of options and locations to chose from.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Great building and close to classes
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I found my own off-campus housing and did not have to go through the school. But everyone that I know that has consulted with UF on off-campus housing has been happy.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Large variety of differnet buildings and cool stuff
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are a huge variety of off campus housing, but many of these housing options force students into year long contracts which is very inconvient. Also, most housing options for summer end before the summer semester which leaves students without a place to live.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The student housing I resided in was very close to my classes, it was also very social which helped me meet a wide variety of my peers who I would not have met otherwise. Although the rooms were very small, I was very glad I decided to live in student housing for my first year.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I've never had to live on campus but I have heard nothing but great things about the on campus living experience. You make life long friends and forge unforgettable memories.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: There are so many off-campus options. The prices are very reasonable if you just do the research. Amenities and Space are wonderful especially compared to dorms. It feels more comfortable to have your own room and bathroom especially at a lower price compared to the dorm. Buses aren't a problem because there are so many stops and routes. But a shorter bus route is better than a longer bus route if you're not a patient type of person, so it's better to choose a place within 10 minutes of campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on campus was a good experience. It helps you to ease into your classes better by becoming acquainted with the University's campus, directional wise. You don't have to worry about monthly utility payments/rent while in school because it was all paid for to begin with therefore alleviating the financial stress during semesters. You are completely surrounded by classsmates of varying backgrounds and cultures allowing you to open your eyes to your school's level of diversity as well as make friends with those in the same boat as you. The cost is a bit higher to live in a confined, cramped space.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: No AC but still good.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The few apartments I have lived in have been okay. I haven't had the best experiences with the maintenance people.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I lived on campus for only one year and the living conditions were alright. They kept it clean for the most part but they need new laundry machines.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I love living on campus because I am so close to my classes. It easy to walk to class and walk back in between in case you forget something or for lunch. I personally also think it is safer to live on campus since most of my exams take place from 8:00-10:00pm at night.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There is more than enough to choose from when you are looking for off-campus housing. Its just up to you to find the right fit.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus is great because you are in close proximity to the various events on campus. It also allows you to form some close bonds to people. However, as we are somewhat of a party school, if you live in a dorm with community bathrooms, be prepared to deal with the after effects of others' partying. Fair warning, custodians don't come in during the weekend and most of your peers won't want to clean up after themselves. Other than that, the rooms are adequate for what you need during school. The AC units in my experience were always working well.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus at UF definitely has its perks. The dorms especially on the east side of campus, such as Broward, Rawlings, Mallory, Beaty Towers, and others are very convenient to get to classes. The dorms towards the center of campus such as Murphree as well as Graham are close to the stadium and gym facilities. The dorms in general are moderately clean and the room sizes in most dorms are decent. The RAs usually do nice things for the residents like baking cookies or having fun meetings.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I am going into my first of-campus apartment next semester, so I can only rate the experience so far. Touring the apartment and signing the lease was a very easy process, and the cost is extremely reasonable, especially compared to dorms and how much more off-campus housing has to offer in terms of privacy and independence.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus is as convenient as it gets. You're close to just about everything you'd need, and if you feel walking or biking to your destination is too much there is always a bus stop nearby. Dorms are decent, though I'd definitely recommend not living in a community dorm if you like your privacy. Amenities are great, especially for fitness and activities. Social atmosphere directly relates to who you hang out with, and can be both fun and studious.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Gainesville is primarily a college town so the number of apartments/ rentable houses is nearly limitless. However, convenience and quality do come with a price so it really depends on how much you are willing to spend on proximity and quality! Usually: good quality and close proximity $$$, Good quality and relatively close proximity $$, not so good quality but close proximity $. There is also very good quality but not very good proximity: $$. Although be careful when looking at prices because some places are unfurnished and/ or don't include utilities in their monthly cost. There are also places that are joint lease only (usually places more for town residents than college students) so don't be fooled by the prices and be careful on where you sign!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on campus is very convenient depending on the dorm you choose. Lakeside and Springs are a little out of the way but the bus system is pretty reliable and can get you to the center of campus in about 5 minutes.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The Dorms were small dirty and  unsocial
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Trying it out this year, it's alright
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It very clean and a good atmosphere
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: To anyone looking to attend UF, I'd say as soon as you are done with the dorms move off-campus. I know the dorms seem convenient and nice, but you can't beat the off-campus housing. There are an incredible number of options, and most are actually cheaper and way bigger than anything you can find on-campus. Also, it is super easy to find an apartment that is right for you. Many websites exist that can help you filter through results and find the best match. Or, if you'd rather talk to a human you can walk right in to any leasing office and can copies of floor plans and prices right then and there. The staff are always really nice and can set up tours for you very quickly. I have lived off-campus for 3 years now and can tell you that I will never go back to a dorm!
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I lived on campus for one year while attending the University of Florida. My dorm was fairly small, and cost as much as an apartment in which I wouldn't have had to share my bedroom (which I definitely did while staying on campus). However, the amenities were great. I had access to a kitchen and bathroom in which someone else cleaned. The common room had a balcony and a flat screen TV in which we could hang out or study. There was also an affordable laundry facility on site. In addition, I had access to an art studio and art gallery (the dorm was populated by many art students) though I personally did not use them. At other dorms on campus there were other amenities that I also had access to. This included access to several swimming pools, two gyms, a couple of billiards tables, meditation rooms, and many other great amenities that were included in the cost of my dorm. Overall, I had a positive experience living on campus and would recommend it to any freshman or sophomore looking to make some close friends and live 5 minutes away from class!
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The campus is beautiful. It has great scenery and the red brick is breath taking. The dorm I live in is Beaty West. Although it's small, its very cozy and comes with a kitchen and a bathroom and two rooms. (Two people per room). I love that the campus has two gyms. They are my favorite part of the entire school. The social atmosphere has a lot to do with Greek Life
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: So much better than living in a dorm. Only thing I have against it is there are some awful landlords running around but some are wonderful.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The only good thing is it's close to class. The people you live with are awful and you end up far too close to them. I moved off campus the year following my life in a dorm.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Definitely the way to go. You have much bigger living areas off campus and I've heard it's much cheaper.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: In my freshman year of college, I have already lived in two dorms, one in the summer, another in the fall and spring. My first dorm experience, Springs, was a rather good one, with the rooms being quite spacious. It's not a very social hall, which, for the time being, was nice, as I was able to bond with my suitemates, and study for exams peacefully. It's not very close to the main part of campus, though the bus system is very efficient and can take you across campus in no time. Plus, the isolationism is nice in the summer when there aren't many students attending. My current dorm, Reid Hall, is more traditional in its style, with smaller (mainly) double rooms across each floor, which, along with the lounge area at the end of the hall, contributes to making it a social dorm, which, in the fall and spring, is almost crucial; I've become friends with almost everyone on my floor. Reid is part of the Yulee complex building, which includes the dorms, Yulee, Mallory, and Reid. With social events at the beginning of each semester and onward, there being a whole complex with multiple dorms opens windows for people to meet others. And, it is in close proximity to much of the campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing is better than on-campus housing, its much cheaper.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The amenities for dorms are alright, but the most frustrating are the rules involved and the limited options you have to decorate.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's really affordable and are at a great proximity of campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I really enjoy living on campus, it gives you a great opportunity to meet new people.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I did not live on campus my freshman or sophmore year, but the housing seems okay according to my friends. All of the dorms are close to classes and centered around the heart of campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: If you can find the right place it's great.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The rooms are clean and the RA staff is friendly. Sometimes i wish I had more space or quiet time though.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Moving into campus housing was extremely easy and welcoming. There was staff all along the street to direct us to where we needed to go and they were all extremely friendly. The dorms were clean when we arrived and mine personally was very spacious. My dorm is directly across from the ROTC building which is essential to be on PT days and helped a lot during my first year of college.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I lived in a dorm my freshman year and shared a room with another girl and then shared a kitchen and bathroom with two other girls. It was like a little apartment! Loved it
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Best dorm for freshman is Broward. Anyone older that wants to live in a dorm should live in Beaty or Springs. Springs is nice but on the very edge of campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I haven't had the full experience yet.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing is relatively average all around.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are a ton of apartments, but not many for a good price close to campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I am with obnoxious roommates, but other than that it is a great experience.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Since the campus housing situation isn't excellent, there is a HUGE selection of off-campus housing at UF. There are options in midtown, downtown, on archer and many more. Whatever your price range, there's something for you. Whether you want furnished, unfurnished, utilities included, parking included, a pool, etc.; you'll be able to find a place that fits all of your needs.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: My experience with campus housing was not a great one. I applied early for housing and ended up being put in an apartment-style room that I would have to move away from after the first semester. The building I was moved into next was also apartment style and was significantly more expensive as well as extremely far from classes; I did not have much choice in the matter. The cleaning of the bathrooms was done with a lick and a promise, almost literally and was never satisfactory. Neither of my RA's were ever around and there wasn't much of a sense of community in either building.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: If we had more space in the rooms I would say it's the best.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Good but too far and bad buses.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I found my apartment through Trimark Properties, and I absolutely love it. It's 100 times better than the dorms, and the prices are similar. Their maintenance is the absolute best. If you have a problem they'll be at your apartment within hours. Their apartments are very modern and well-equipped. Best thing about living with Trimark is that I'm steps away from campus, so I can walk anywhere.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Only live in a dorm if you know who you're going to be living with. Their lottery system is terrible, they'll assign to someone who you're not compatible with.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Depending on where you live and what building you live in, off-campus housing can range from fair to excellent.  Each landlord is different, but in general, having the opportunity to have your own bedroom is something that I love.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living on campus was a great experience and I am incredibly glad I chose to do so.  Living on-campus allowed me to become acclimated with campus and introduced me to many new friends.  It is definitely something I recommend.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I paid more for getting half a room and access to a common bathroom, than I do now with my own bedroom and bathroom.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I will be living off-campus next year and the place I found is really cheap and a 10 minute walk from campus, which I love.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The major problem with where I live is the building is very old, so the elevators brake often. I live on the 12th floor, which makes it difficult to get to my dorm when the elevators are not working.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: All depends on where you end up and who your land lord is.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It is extremely uncleanly carpeting and outdated furniture in the dorms. The price exceeds the quality.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I live in an nice dorm / apartment with 3 other girls. We have our own bedroom which is great. There are 2 bathrooms. I am a little out from my classes but the bus service is excellent and it has never been an issue getting to my classes. The cost of where I am residing is a little more expensive than if I was in a dorm right in the middle of the campus. I am close to a gym and it is a quiet area that I live in. The post office is across the street and there is a nice lake that I can walk to that is a nice place to relax and study. The only thing is that places for me to eat that are on my meal card are right on campus and once I get back to my dorm I do not go back to campus to eat. I make alot of my own meals and a grocery store is not far from my apartment. All in all I do like it the I live on the edge of the campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's very hard to live out of the space provided, but it is manageable for a first year college experience. The RAs did a good job trying to socialize the floors and facilitate group events. The roommate pairing system isn't perfect, but it did not go horribly wrong in my case.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I don't know much about it yet, but there are lots of places around campus, that are affordable on a college budget and financial aid. And that are understanding
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's a great ay to make friends, but the rooms and small and you're sharing sith someone else. Some are clased to classes others, it'll take a little bit to get there. The people are great, the pools are nice, so are the convinence stores.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: A lot of students live off campus and its sometimes good cause you get more privacy
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Overall, the school is not bad. It is very affordable for in-state students and the faculty is helpful.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I lived in lakeside, the  summer of my freshmen year. There were 4 rooms, a shared kitchen, and bathroom. It was a normal dorm experience and my roommates were nice. However, Lakeside is far from campus and to get to class on time you have to take the bus everyday. It was difficult to get to campus on weekends when the buses didn't run regularly. I now live in Windsor, which is a lot closer to campus and sorority row. If you are going to join a sorority, Windsor is a better option.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: My roommates and I were able to find an apartment and sign a lease really easily.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love it so incredibly much. My roommate is great, my RA is great, my cleaning staff is friendly, I'm close to the pool and dining hall, and the buses are very convenient.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There's a little bit of everything to choose from.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Overall, campus housing at UF is a great value.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The apartments that are in walking distance are high priced but others, further away, are cheaper.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's a extremely outdated but in an excellent location.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I'm currently in an apartment and it's great
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I lived in a dorm freshman year.  It was very nice and comfortable, just a little pricey.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most apartments are friendly, but if they aren't really expensive, they're really dirty. Basically, you have to pick and choose what's more important to you: cleanliness, price, proximity, etc.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on campus is typically the best choice for freshmen. It allows them to meet new people and get plugged in. However, That's only if they put in the effort to. It is also difficult if you do not get along with your roommate. Living on campus can be great for making new friends and getting "plugged in" but it can also be the biggest factor that drives students away from completing school.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I have no problem with where I live off-campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living off campus is a much wiser choice than living on campus. It's cheaper to have an apartment with a room and bathroom to yourself off-campus than it is to share one room with two other girls in a dorm that has no a/c unit, with bathrooms that have no locks or even stalls to protect individuals in the showers (and I lived in the cheapest dorm). Apartments closest to campus are generally for the more wealthy demographic and are generally not an option for anyone else. The best choices are apartments and houses. I didn't even realize help could be found through the school, it's possible there isn't help at all. I don't see why the school would take it upon themselves to locate off-campus housing for students unless it was overflow housing at Oakbrook Walk. Living off campus is always the wiser option. Parking varies from place to place, some apartments require decals or have allotted visitor parking. Some houses are located in neighborhoods that require permits in order to simply park on the street. Having a car off-campus is pretty pointless anyways since parking options at UF are the worst and most unaccommodating I've probably ever seen. If you have a scooter you're better off, but the weather conditions in Gainesville don't allow for it to be a pleasurable experience on most days.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The farther from campus or the older the apartment, usually the cheaper it is, unless it is on a bus route, and then the price quadruples.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The housing on campus is adequate for first year life, and allows residents to get involved in the freshman community.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live off campus so I can't say much about the campus housing, however, the lottery system could be better. It appears that graduate campus housing near the hospital is very limited.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: It serves its purpose, and it is better and cheaper than living on campus.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: There are tons of places to live off campus ranging from right next to the main part of campus to a few miles away. Obviously the closer to campus you are, the more expensive it is so its a tradeoff between price and location but it is overall not bad.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live at lakeside and it is super far from everything, especially without any form of transportation outside of the bus and my own legs, but it is really nice. It is super close to the better gym and has its own full kitchen and living room in each apartment. You also get your own bedroom and share a bathroom with one other person which is super nice. Most other dorms are located closer to classes but they all have their tradeoffs. Hume is large and pretty close but super expensive and mostly for honors students. Beaty is close to campus and apartment style but the rooms are small and you share them. Overall, it isn't too bad and you figure out how to live with the tradeoff and like where you are.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: tons of places to live off campus, research before you sign a lease
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I lived in a double in Jennings my freshman year. It was just a normal dorm experience. There was a big shared bathroom - if you're living there I would recommend shower shoes and a towel wrap. It was also pretty loud and you could hear people talking when they walked past your door. The location wasn't bad, but if I were to be a freshman again, I would probably pick Lakeside or Windsor so I wouldn't have to share a communal bathroom.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: There are a bunch of options in different price ranges. It's easy to find your perfect fit.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: There's a lot of options for students to chose from.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: So convenient living on campus, especially since I live in East Hall and one of the dining halls is right next to me.  Really can't complain about the distance between here and my classes, either, the walk is always nice.  I love the social atmosphere of the dining halls, half met a lot of my friends there.  Overall cost for everything (housing, meal plan, books, tuition, etc) is a bit pricey, but what can you do?  Housing process could be a bit more foolproof.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus was not a bad experience, however I will never live on campus again. It was too expensive.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I lived in Jennings and it was really nice, always clean, and such a social atmosphere.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Lakeside complex is a nice dorm however it is not walking distance to campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Love the pricing but I would appreciate more space.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: I lived in two complexes off-campus and it was decent.  But, I am now living in grad housing on campus
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: I currently live in on campus dorms and I love it because of how close it is to my classes. At most have a 15 minute walk but I never have to rely on RTS living on campus. It is also extremely convenient at night if you have sport practices or clubs.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Typically not walking distance to the school but usually very accessible to RTS bus system. Off campus housing is generally very well maintained and has a lot more convienent parking than on campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
I'm currently a junior and have lived in five different residence halls since I was a freshman, specifically Murphree, Jennings, Riker, Lakeside, and Broward. All of these halls are IMMENSELY different and the one you'll like the most really depends on what you're looking for 

Murphree is popular because of it's proximity to classes and how it looks, but I hated it for its old facilities and because the common area is separate from any of the halls in the area, doing laundry is a pain because of the long walk from your room to the commons, which seems even longer when you're carrying several weeks' worth of laundry! If you're on a meal plan, the only nearby food is Moe's.

Jennings is more recently renovated and has nicer facilities and lots of space in it's common area and basement. However, there were a lot of rowdy girls on my floor who would make a ton of noise in the hallway at 2 a.m. on a weekday night and would slam doors and puke in the hall while I'm trying to sleep. Also, while I might have just gotten really unlucky, people on my floor were absolutely DISGUSTING with leaving the bathroom a complete mess.

Riker is not renovated and the Tolbert Area is not the closest to campus, but it's definitely not as far as other areas (plus numerous buses run by it) and you're right behind Gator Corner if you're on a meal plan. I also had a single, so that made it all worth it.

Lakeside's distance is terrible, as is its $3,000+ price per semester and it has the same laundry room issues as Murphree. But it's not bad if you can look past those things. You get you're own room (albeit a tiny one), a bathroom you only have to share with one other person, and your own kitchen.

Broward has been my favorite by far. It's the most recently renovated hall, is the closest to campus, has tons of places to study and hang out, and there's a Chick-Fil-A right next door! I also lucked out with a huge single that is a few square feet away from being the size of a double.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: There are many, many options right next to campus where you can walk in about 5 or 10 minutes. The only downside of campus housing is it can be very pricey.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in an economy triple. It is a room made for 2 people, and they stuck my initial roommate and I with an extra person. It ended up being fine because we all get along great, but it is extremely small. I live in Broward. Broward and Jennings are the most social dorms and are right next to classes. Rawlings is pretty social too. Murphree and Springs on the other hand are extremely far, and you have to take a bus or walk 20 minutes to get to class.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: ON campus housing is pretty good. It's clean and its a great way to make friends.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The only problem there is with off campus housing is year long leases because most students leave in the summer.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: My apartment is good for its price
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Its kind of small when I visit friends
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I'm really having to do my research but it's fine
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's great cause of location and the ability to just walk to classes. Unless you pay for the more expensive dorms, there's really no privacy. You don't get your own bathroom or your own bedroom.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: TONS OF PLACES TO LIVE OFF CAMPUS. Usually they're pretty affordable and there is a wide range of housing types and quality.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Moving off campus will save you some money per month.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore
